cons:
Politics is bad, everybody can have opinion about everything and block progress without any particular knowledge about the subject.  There is a lot of schmoozers who hve spent years at the company are not getting fired because of the years spent.

Insecurity and incompetence at TI is at a very high level, other divisions are much better but TI does not have P/L valuation and has really diverged from the mainstream business (though this is true for most of the IT's in financials).

Young people are hired but not given challenges and opportunities.  They really hve to become schmoozers to get any recognition and spend 10 years to see growth (if they are not schmoozers).  If you are a schmoozer, you can make VP in 5-6 years.

Company is also known for hiding its titles, they tell you there are only Associates, Vice Presidents and Managing Directors.  Well, it turns out to become MD you have to go through 4 promotions from Vice President and each one takes two years (exceptions are possible but rare).

job_title: Vice President Technology in New York, NY
pros:
Good on your resume
Will meet hard working people .
cons:
constant cost cutting initiatives.
Goldman technology feels they are great in technology and different than other firms.Surprisingly these comments only come from people who have never worked outside the firm. Reality is  that they are not really different and in fact their technology is very out dated resulting in hard work for people and difficult release cycle.
Everyone I meet has a constant fear of layoffs. They are just hanging in there till the inevitable layoffs happens
Not a good option for 10+ years experience laterals.Most would be used for layoffs bucket or lower ratings in appraisal cycle
Benefits that used to great are declining every year.health benefits premiums and deductible has increased a lot
No work from home even for genuine cases
All in all not worth the hard work you put in. Better compensation/work life balance outside

The whole firm is pushing toward outsourcing to save money.
It has a 20-20 rule. Be prepared to work 20%more on 20% less salary than competitors
They will really keep an eye on you on every small things like when you come to office,how may breaks  youtake etc

review_title: Misogynist, racist, anti-Semitic boss.  Run away NOW.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: None. None. None. None. None.
cons:
I was unfortunate enough to be stuck with a misogynist, racist, and anti-Semitic manager.  Example: When setting the support rota for April, he waited until I went to lunch, sat down with everyone else on my team, and pulled out a calendar and deliberately scheduled me to be on call during Passover.  (He himself never took call.)  Another example: I was held at fault for "arriving late" every time there was a delay on the Metro-North commuter rail or the subway.  Yet another example: There was a subway strike while I was at GS.  All employees who had to take the subway were allowed to telecommute for the duration of the strike.  My manager was not affected by the strike.   He wrote me up for telecommuting because it was "unnecessary" -- for HIM.

I did my best to deal with the situation, but it was untenable.  I approached upper management, who told me to deal with it.   I ultimately dealt with it by quitting for my own mental health and finding a job in Midtown Manhattan where they understood that delays on Metro-North were Metro-North's fault, not mine.

And their idea of work/life balance is "if you have time for a life, you obviously don't have enough work to do, so here's some more!"

People don't leave companies, they leave managers.  I left mine.

pros: Good company culture and work culture
cons: little space to grow within the company

pros: Ample training on topics.  No issues regarding taking time off.
cons: There is a carrot that is being waved in front of your face at all times.  Becoming an account manager is the holy grail.  Unfortunately, becoming an account manager is not a reflection of your hard work, it's a reflection of whether your SVP cares about you or not.   If you stay an FA, you will be paid less than your counterparts at other financial planning firms.  You'll always be asked for excellence as a jack of all trades but get little in return.  They account manager you work for can make or break you and if you're an attorney you have a huge leg up on those who are not.  There's a buffer between you and your SVP who is supposed to guide you along in your career, but wait until you see how unimpressive they are.  The problem stems from senior management, "pay them more" has always been the answer, but management couldn't care less.  You know it's bad when at the Christmas parties your CEO has to combine the 401(k) match with the "bonus" (about $600) to make it look like they're rewarding you at the end of the year.  Oh yeah, the 401(k) match is a little over 1%.  I think the only thing that is comparable with other companies is the vacation time.

pros: Great team great learning overall
cons: Work hours can be tough for some

pros: The prestige and exit opps
cons: Nothing that was not expected by the industry

pros: GS hires some very smart people. The competence in terms of technology is actually quite amazing. There is a lot of emphasis on consensus and working together as a team. I had heard a number of people complain about the hours and the constant pressure etc., but I have not personally seen it. There are the occasional delivery pressures, but it is not constant. Work-life balance is quite ok. The company offers a lot in terms of benefits for its employees. There is also ample room for growth for the right people.
cons: Most of the cons are the usual ones in working for a large company. Technology processes are heavy in bureaucracy - to some extent this is understandable, but this impacts productivity. The number of meetings that one has to attend sometimes tends to take focus away from the job. It is very difficult to get something done unless you are in the top echelons of the management - even though there is a lot of emphasis on people being driven and motivated. Developers are required to do development, QA, and production support. This does not make for very productive developers.

job_title: Senior Associate Consultant in London, England
pros: Well organized company, Good management
cons: Not competitive enough for freshers

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Brand Name, large organization, global firm
cons: Not meritocratic anymore. Toxic work culture.

pros: Good pay and good benefits
cons: No cons at Goldman Sachs

pros: good brand name and plateform
cons: limited career path and grwoth

job_title: Operations Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits... Health care, 401k, all the best.  If you like operations work, this is the place to be.  Ranked as the top employer in Utah.
cons: For working in Salt Lake City, it pays well.  However, a same-level operations analyst in NYC/Jersey City makes much more.  Further, much of your pay is based on performance bonus, which reviews are heavily biased and leaves room for wage discrimination.  Immediate management is out-of-touch.  Merit rewards no one... if you'd like to succeed, be sure to network well and create the perception of value.  Emphasis on "perception".  Overtime pay is half-time... but if you work any less than 50 hours/week, you'll yourself in a serious "conversation" with your manager--regardless as to whether you have work left to do.  Again, the perception of being a valuable employee, and this includes just working late for the sake of working late, is what matters.  But if you still want the job, make sure you play to Goldman's egos, as they like to hear how "big-deal" they are, because they work for a "big-deal" company.  There are very few finance roles at GS Salt Lake City... it is a major operations hub for GS.

review_title: Add value to the firm, but don't forget to add value to yourself
pros: Some of the smartest people work at Goldman Sachs. For an intern/graduate it is a good place to learn and start building a career. Depending on the team you could be working with cutting-edge technology. If working in front office teams you will have plenty of exposure to the business side of things.
cons:
As with many large organisations, the experience of working at Goldman Sachs is greatly dependent on which team you end up working for, since the style, culture, and compensation varies wildly between teams. In terms of compensation, the business-aligned divisions will be a lot of better off.

In technology, it is extremely painful to get any change approved, due to the many layers of management and bureaucracy. Also, the software development practices used in certain front office teams are truly shocking - hardly any unit testing, no collaboration. The code for some of the most critical trading functions seems to be randomly cobbled together until it finally works in production.

pros: Some nice people on the lower levels that make going to work worthwhile.  The office locations tend to be really good.
cons: No internal promotions for women or graduates who are always seen as the 'grad' doing monkey work. Management is seriously unprofessional, no qualms about gas-lighting and taking credit for other staffs work.  Managers peers then hide the unethical behaviours like not showing up to work for days on end, or forcing new mothers out of roles they've held for years, disgustingly leaving HR have to run to cover their behinds from lawsuits by making leavers sign their rights away with for their last paychecks being released.  Graduates are treated terribly, doing grunt-work and sent on 2 month 'training' in New York initially which always woos the young new starters but making them fly cattle-class in the cheapest seats possible (supposedly one of the best finance companies in the world?? really??), away from family and friends for extended periods, only to later see that they will never be promoted properly, they need to leave to get anywhere in their careers as they will never be taken seriously otherwise.

review_title: SO bad you have to see it to believe it
pros: Account Manager positions are paid well. Competitive PTO benefits.
cons:
Management is inept and is not able to fix the mass amounts of poor processes and bureaucracy that plague the organization. Years of poor financial performance, layoffs, overworked and underplayed staff has taken a tremendous toll on morale. Many employees openly discuss looking for opportunities elsewhere; most are treated as a human cog in the machine that this company has become. Most benefits are not competitive tot he market and healthcare premiums are affordable. Many employees have had several years of lower take home pay as a result of compensation practices and poor benefits. Long days are the norm and expected by all levels of associates. Staff are expected to be at the office rain sleet or snow and lack of working modern technology requires positions that should not need to be in the office travel in inclement weather.  All positions other than Account Manager's are paid well below market. There is no tangible presence of diversity of employee or thought. 

Working here you will live the adage "the emperor has no clothes."

pros: Even though I was laid off, I will always be grateful for the experience of working at Goldman.  I was afforded the opportunity to interact with some of the most intelligent yet down to earth people.  The oportunities for learning and being exposed to different layers of management was always a plus.  Intentional effort was placed on making sure that mentoring was in place.  The name recognition is worth its weight in gold.  Because Goldman is known for employing the best talent, being accepted as an authority in your respective field of expertise is almost a given.  Wouldn't trade the experience for anything.
cons: Unless you were willing to relocate, there were not enough advancement opportunities.  A more streamlined approach to cultural integration is needed.

review_title: Sweet and sour experience - started sweet, going sour
job_title: Senior Analyst Developer in London, England
pros:
Name looks good on cv. 
Ability to work globally with wide variety of people. 
Good internal training facilities - classroom and e-learning courses and talks by internal/external industry experts. 
Gym has just been refurbished.
cons:
Pay is significantly down and now well under market rate (both base and overall total comp)
Reviews are a joke - supposedly 360 degree but manager has total veto rights on everything and can skew review any way they like meaning you need to seriously brown nose to get ahead.  Obviously contradicts the image of a meritocracy that they like to portray. 
Toxic environment due to understaffing and off shoring work (and lack of pay) - no development done in London any more.  London is mainly used to manage offshore resources. 
Yearly 5% cull, somehow people never seem to get replaced. The way its done is not very good for team spirit as it doesn't all happen in one batch, rather is stretched out into 2/3 sessions weeks or even months apart.

review_title: A growth opportunity, learning to think and work strategically
job_title: Operations Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The benefits can not be beat. 
Work with mostly intelligent people.
High stake responsibilities given to you on day one.
Everyday can be a challenge to overcome but over time you'll see your own growth and realize you are stronger than you thought possible.
cons:
Management is never trained. They pick top performers and promote them to mangers- unfortunately most lack the interpersonal skill set needed to be a great leader. 
The stress is through the roof. You breathe the wrong way and they assume you broke an account. 
The hours are unruly - they will never tell you to go home. They will continue to overload your plate with more than you can manage and expect it to be perfect. 
No real training. Follows the monkey see monkey do attitude. 
Politics. The worst! Need to ensure you brown nose the right people to get promoted and make a difference.

pros: Some of the people here are very nice and welcoming.  Goldman Sachs on my resume was definitely a plus. Great place to start - good experience .
cons: The processes are clunky and technology is absolutely horrible.   As an FA, I worked extremely long hours, especially during tax season.  For the low and well below market value pay, not worth the long hours and stress (unless you are an Account Manager, because they get paid a ton).  They took away tax compensation, which is incredibly unfair for all the hard work and long hours you put in.  Worst of all, there  is nepotism in the Operations department-  as a result they are very biased and management tolerates this.  Needless to say, I happily resigned after finding a much better employer.  This place is a terrible place to work. Not just the company but this particular office.  If you don’t mind dealing with long hours, low pay and unfair nepotism from the exec side than this is the place for you!! Otherwise, please do yourself a favor and steer clear.

review_title: Great company focused on its people, culture, and high-expectations to succeed
job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great people, incredible amount of knowledge in this company. Senior management is willing to help analysts out with no. Culture is very teamwork oriented and focused on diversity. I worked with people from all backgrounds and was hard pressed to find someone who wasn't unique. They really want you to work beyond expectations and deliver 110% on everything; the quintessential driving force of Goldman Sachs. Typically, every employee is respectful of the competition and rarely, if ever, downplays the rival banks. Also, employees are required to participate in community teamwork projects. These helped build relationships with co-workers and showed the company has a general interest in giving back.
cons: There are a few people who are quite condescending when you require information from them. Sometimes it makes the job harder to do and the goal of success tough to reach. Also, the name often goes to people's heads and they exude somewhat of an ego.

review_title: Competitive salary/benefits, strong work ethic, management "by committee"
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
- Best-and-brightest colleagues, hard-working teams, mentor program
- Excellent benefits program, onsite childcare, continuing education/training
- Flexible work arrangements
- Strong focus on diversity, accountability, integrity, team-building 
- High level of trust from management, overall
- Great onsite cafeteria (though pricey)
cons:
- Management tends to have strong focus on managing up, not enough on team
- Hard work isn't always rewarded, you have to be comfortable flagging your accomplishments to the right people
- Intense pressure for perfection, high level of scrutiny at all levels
- Challenging culture to fit into as a "lateral hire" (i.e., if you started your career elsewhere); often feels like you're the new kid in school and you have to prove yourself worthy before the team will accept you
- Must be able/willing to set your own boundaries (i.e., work-life balance) - if you won't, no one else will
- IT lacking; steps being taken to improve and update, but process is slow and new systems are often rolled out before sufficiently user-tested
- Intense interview process; you'll likely interview with at least a dozen people before getting an offer

review_title: Fantastic place to be at the start of your career
pros:
Smart people, tonnes of responsibility very early on, exciting environment, always looking to progress/ change, international opportunities in some divisions, relatively flat structure but only in so much as senior people are required to know the detail.  

Undoubtedly one of the best investment banks to start your career in - new joiners are super eager and excited and will work all the hours they can to get noticed and make progress.

Remuneration is very good compared to other sectors, and is normally marked to market every 3 years to make sure they stay slightly ahead of the competition.  Good years are excellent, bad years are flat.
cons:
Although they have taken great strides to try to address lack of workplace flexibility and acceptance of alternative ways of working, they still have a long way to go, and are most certainly losing out to the tech sector when it comes to new hires who don't just want to work 14 hour days.  

Promotion whilst on flexible working is virtually unheard of, and they do a pretty bad job managing transition periods over maternity leaves.  Many female employees leave due to being sidelined as a result of absence during a maternity leave - huge knowledge waste for such a smart organisation.

review_title: Great benefits, but beware of what job you take
pros: Great benefits, great location, competitive pay and mostly great and very talented people.
cons:
The company is very siloed. If you get hired into one division and want to transfer to another division, you will have a hard time doing so. This is especially true for administrative positions.  Do NOT be fooled into thinking that taking an administrative job at this firm would be a great way to get your foot in the door. Administrative assistants are largely overlooked. Internal training, mentoring, etc are all focused on associates, analysts, and VPs.  The job is a complete and utter deadend. A lot of people are completely dismissive of administrative assistants and won't even bother reading your resume to see what you did prior to that job. 

If you are qualified for other positions and have career ambitions and are hungry for advancement,  do NOT get talked into taking an administrative role. It will be a huge setback for you and a shocking number of people will be completely dismissive of you. You might as well be background furniture.

pros: Location, coworkers, benefits, good for resume
cons: Call Center atmosphere, back to back calls.  They monitor your every move.

pros: Company with great prestige
cons: No one at Goldman is valued. Everyone is disposable, because everyone wants to work there. Except for certain leadership, no one is important enough to even have their own space. Because they feel like they can replace you so easily, they have demands that ridiculous. Expect to work more than 50 hours a week. While they have sone great benefits, it is not worth sacrificing your personal life for a place that doesn't value you. Expect increasing demands that can will easily take over your life. If you're not willing to do that, then they will guilt you into doing it because you're working at GS. If you have depression or anxiety or another of mental illness, expect wellness to treat your illness as an excuse to want some sort of arrangement. They will treat you like a liar, even after meeting with the therapist that is employed by GS. Last thing, if wellness does make an arrangement with you, don't expect it to last. It's like they think that those things will go away after a couple of months.

job_title: Human Resources Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Very good compensation, esteemed company name on your resume.
cons: Little work-life balance. Our team was understaffed and overworked. Manager did not care that we were short on resources and looked at us with fault if we didnt get the job done that only robots could do.  Manager micromanaged us, but did not understand truly what own team was doing and the intricacies involved. That being said, one's experience at GS depends ALL on who your manager is. There are some very able managers, and then some very UNable managers. Some nice managers, and some complete jerks.  As 'esteemed' a place this is, I would never return, and would never encourage someone to work here, if you value worklife balance and refuse to be a 'rat' in the 'race'. Go to one of the Big 4 audit firms instead. Environment is much more enjoyable and pleasant all around.
